awd_abstract_narration:
The Quantum Leap Challenge Institutes (QLCI) program is part of the Quantum Leap, one of the research Big Ideas promoted by the National Science Foundation. This award is a QLCI Conceptualization Grant, which supports activities to build capacity among teams planning for the large-scale, interdisciplinary Challenge Institute projects that aim to advance the frontiers of quantum information science and engineering. Research at these Institutes will span the focus areas of quantum computation, quantum communication, quantum simulation, and/or quantum sensing. The Institutes are expected to foster multidisciplinary approaches to specific scientific, technological, and workforce development goals in these fields.

This Conceptualization Grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Challenge Institute proposal along the theme of quantum photonic integrated circuits.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The activities in this project allowed the proposal team to write a compelling pre-proposal for a Quantum Photonic Institute that would create and use the only U.S-based open-access Quantum Foundry for quantum photonic circuits. The team laid out a series of goals to conceptualize and then write a quantum institute proposal for the NSF Quantum Leap Challenge Institute program including; 1) refining the cross-disciplinary vision, 2) refining the research Themes, 3) choosing the final motivating challenge problems, 4) defining the Institute?s goals and related assessment metrics, 5) defining final team membership, 6) defining goals for industry partnership, 8) validating a Quantum Foundry model by collecting information from AIM Photonics, and other similar facilities, regarding their capabilities and user needs for fabricating, packaging, and testing integrated quantum photonic circuits, 10) finalizing workforce/education goals and strategy, 9) holding the international Photonics for Quantum 2 Workshop (PfQ2), and 10) writing a proposal for a Quantum Leap Challenge Institute and having it reviewed by a ?red team? that will use a list of project-specific milestones and criteria in the call for proposals to assess the readiness of the team to submit a final proposal.

Our team, led by PI Donald Figer, held quarterly meetings to refine its vision define projects, build the leadership team, and pilot workforce and education programs to include in the institute proposal. The team defined unifying research themes: 1) all optical quantum silicon photonics, 2) hybrid quantum materials integration, 3) high-dimensional quantum information, and 4) workforce and education- and projects within those themes to address grand challenges in quantum science and technology and advance quantum computing, sensing, and imaging. Co-PI Ben Zwickl and his team surveyed academic administrators in departments and colleges at collaborating institutions to determine interest and needs for developing quantum curricula across a broad range of related majors. In September 2020, the team submitted the final proposal draft for selection.

While the proposal was not selected, team members created separate proposals for select projects within the QPI proposal, held Photonics for Quantum, and moved forward in workforce and education outreach.

Sponsored in part by our NSF Conceptualization Grant and nine industry sponsors, RIT held Photonics for Quantum 2 during summer 2020. The online meeting included over 500 registrants and 30+ speakers. The virtual program extended over six weeks with one speaker, poster, and sponsor talk per day to allow maximum participation and opportunity for community discussion. The program included a full day for education and workforce development (canceled due to COVID-19), and a panel for Women in Quantum. In 2021, RIT and SPIE collaborated to create a yearly Photonics for Quantum conference using the SPIE platform. RIT and SPIE held the third Photonics for Quantum online in July 2021. The event included a more international program, a Government Panel, an Education Panel lead by QED-C, and a networking session for Women in Quantum. Future Photonics for Quantum Conferences will be held at RIT under the SPIE platform and will have parallel sessions specifically for education and workforce development and a session for Women in Quantum.

Co-PI Zwickl and his PhD student, Mike Verostek, gathered data and developed new partnerships that will support education and workforce development for QIST (Quantum Information Science Technology) careers. In a series of surveys of deans, faculty, and industry they found that quantum information science and technology needs to be taught in adjacent areas in STEM at the undergraduate level, helping to create pathways for interdisciplinary QIST education. The pathways may also include the proposal of new cross-disciplinary electives to fill gaps in the quantum curriculum, as well as identifying expert instructors who could develop those courses.
